From the blog post:

We‚Äôre rolling it out slowly and carefully now, but in such a way that we‚Äôll eventually be able to say with confidence ‚Äúevery message sent by Signal is protected by this.‚Äù Its code has been formally verified, and will continue to be so even as future updates affect the protocol.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
also, SPQR has been making its way into clients‚Äô code since for a while now, so by sometime in early 2026 we can say for sure all clients that don‚Äôt have SPQR will have expired, i.e. 100% of Signal conversations will be SPQR.

github.com/signalapp/libsignal

Integrate post-quantum ratchet SPQR.

committed 06:18PM - 04 Jun 25 UTC
gram-signal
+2366 -260

This PR integrates a post-quantum ratchet (SPQR) into libsignal, using an API th‚Ä¶at maintains its own internal chain and provides per-message keys. In doing so, it also aims to be fully backwards-compatible with current clients and stored session state. ## Backwards compatibility with current clients Remote clients that connect to us or that we connect to may not have this integration. If they don't, their SignalMessage wire format should still deserialize, and in doing so we'll receive an empty pq_ratchet field. SQPR handles this internally, by downgrading the protocol version to "version 0" or "don't do anything". Note that should we eventually want to disallow this, we can do so via increasing the `min_version` field passed into the SQPR init functions to V1. This is also the method by which we would upgrade SQPR from v1 to a future v2, etc. ## Opt-in The publicly facing API calls for this now expose an explicit opt-in via a passed-in `use_pq_ratchet` bool (and associated enums in language-specific APIs). If false, they default to SQPR `v0`, IE: none. If true, they try to set up SPQR on new sessions, but will downgrade if the remote party cannot or will not do the same.

posts.cooked: Senatus Popolusque Romanus ?

posts.name: Cruggmo
posts.cooked:
Very interesting read. I‚Äôm curious about this bit:

Crucially, SPQR only allows a downgrade when it first receives a message from a remote party. So, Bob can only downgrade if he receives his first message from Alice and notices that she doesn‚Äôt support SPQR, and Alice will only downgrade if she receives her first reply from Bob and notices that he doesn‚Äôt. After that first back-and-forth, SPQR is locked in and used for the remainder of the session.

How does this protocol accommodate a single user with multiple (up to 5) clients, with varying versions and support for SPQR? Consider this scenario:

Alice [android client, supports SPQR] sends a message to bob (supporting SPQR)

Bob [any client, supporting SPQR] receives the message. He replies to alice, using SPQR

Alice [android client, supports SPQR] receives initial reply, establishing SPQR for the long-lived session and preventing any downgrade

-later-

Bob sends another message, using SPQR as has been established

Alice checks her signal messages, using an outdated desktop client that does not support SPQR

How would this play out?

I‚Äôm getting a ton of undeliverable message errors, all of which implicate the post-quantum ratchet in the debug logs. Could this be the reason?
Looking forward to see more info on the docs siteüòÄ
